title: 103_hr4476
content: The "National Park System Reform Act of 1994" is also known as the National Park System Plan. This Act includes the preparation of a plan for the National Park System. The Secretary of the Interior, through the Director of the National Park Service, is tasked with preparing a National Park System Plan to guide the direction of the system. The plan includes goals, criteria for resource inclusion, representation of national heritage, and identification of appropriate aspects. The National Park System Plan includes goals, criteria for resource inclusion, representation of national heritage, priorities for adding resources, the role of the National Park Service, and consultation with other agencies and officials. The Secretary shall consult with various agencies, officials, and organizations to develop a plan for the National Park System. The plan will be transmitted to Congress within three fiscal years of enactment. SEC. 102. MANAGEMENT REVIEW OF NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. The Secretary will review the National Park System to determine if there are better management alternatives, considering factors like duplication, resource representation, and visitor accessibility. A report will list areas where National Park Service management should be modified or terminated. The Secretary will review the National Park System to identify areas where management by entities other than the National Park Service is recommended. Consultation with various stakeholders will be conducted, and a report will be transmitted to Congress within one year of completing the plan. The Secretary will transmit a report to Congress containing recommendations for modifications or termination of National Park Service management for certain areas within the National Park System, as well as suggestions for alternative management by other entities. SEC. 103. NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM REVIEW COMMISSION. Establishment of Commission: If the Secretary fails to transmit the report within the specified 1-year period, a National Park System Review Commission will be established to review existing units for potential management modifications or terminations. The Commission will submit a report to the relevant Congressional committees within one year, listing areas for potential management changes and suggesting alternative entities for management. Feasible alternatives to National Park Service management will be identified for areas of national significance before inclusion on the list. The Commission shall consult with Federal land managing agencies, State and local officials, and other interested parties to identify feasible alternatives to National Park Service management for areas of national significance. The Commission shall consist of 7 members with substantial familiarity with the National Park System, appointed by the Secretary, Speaker of the House, and President Pro Tem of the Senate. Each member must be appointed within 3 months after the 1-year period specified in section 102(c). The Commission shall elect a chair from among its members, vacancies shall not affect the authority of remaining members, a simple majority constitutes a quorum, meetings shall be held quarterly or upon majority call, members serve without compensation but are entitled to travel expenses, and the Commission can be terminated. The Commission established under this section shall terminate 90 days after the report is transmitted to Congress. The Commission may hire staff, with no more than half being National Park Service employees. Other federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission. The Commission can procure temporary services and hold public hearings for its purpose. The Commission established under this section has powers to hold public hearings, make bylaws, and receive information from the Secretary. They can also use the United States mails and terminate 90 days after transmitting the report to Congress. SEC. 201. STUDY OF NEW PARK SYSTEM AREAS. Section 8 of the Act of August 18, 1970 is amended to include a new subsection (b) requiring the Secretary to submit a list of areas recommended for study for potential inclusion in the National Park System to the relevant committees annually. The Secretary must submit a list of areas recommended for study for potential inclusion in the National Park System, giving consideration to national significance, suitability, and feasibility. Special attention should be given to themes, sites, and resources not well-represented in the system. No new studies for inclusion can be initiated without specific authorization from Congress. The National Park Service retains the authority to conduct assessments, gather data, provide assistance, and update previous studies. The Secretary must complete studies for potential National Park System inclusion within 3 fiscal years of legislation enactment. Studies must involve public input and consider national significance of natural or cultural resources. The Secretary must conduct studies to determine if an area has significant natural or cultural resources and is suitable for addition to the National Park System. Factors considered include resource rarity, threats, public use potential, costs, public support, and long-term protection. Management by the National Park Service or other agencies is also evaluated. Each study evaluates whether National Park Service management or alternative protection is suitable for the area, identifying the most effective option for resource protection and public enjoyment. The Secretary submits a list of areas with cultural or natural resources for potential addition to the National Park System, prioritizing based on threats and significance. The Secretary submits a prioritized list of areas with cultural or natural resources for potential addition to the National Park System, considering threats and significance. The House of Representatives passed the bill on September 28, 1994.
